passages.text: Demographic shifts, changes in policy/regulations and inflation/interest rate uncertainty continue to drive debates on investment attractiveness of Sustainability- related themes and funds. These debates — which we expect to be heavily discussed at our 2025 Global Sustainability Forum, to be held on September 25 in New York City — include the pace/focus of Green Capex, Al/data center power demand and how demand will be sourced, Aging Populations impact on Labor/spending trends, Infrastructure needs and broader Innovation/Efficiencies in Water, Power, Energy, Resources and Land, global Regulations and Sustainability Metrics that Matter. We continue to see revenue tailwinds for companies levered to: (a) Reliability of Power/Water/Energy; (b) Efficiency of Energy/Resources/Land; and (c) Future of Work.
In this report, we highlight 5 key themes we expect to be in focus and on the agenda for the September 25 Global Sustainability Forum. These include:

1. Sustainable Investing outlook, Navigating Uncertainty, Regulation and the Way Forward  
2. Reliability: Meeting Power, Water & Energy Demand Amid Growth, Aging Infrastructure/Populations and Extreme Temperatures/Weather Events  
3. Al & Innovation's Sustainability Impact  
4. Tying Sustainability to Performance, Capital Flows and Risks  
5. Efficiency & Circular Economy: Reducing Consumption Intensity Without Impacting Quality of Life
Please click here for registration for the September 25 Global Sustainability Forum, which will be held in person in New York City.

Goldman Sachs does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html. Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.

Enabling Reliable Connectivity, Innovation & Decarbonization in Spain, Texas & Beyond: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas - Garrett Golding, Assistant VP for Energy Programs; Repsol - Luis Cabra, EMD, Energy Transition, Technology, and Institutional Affairs, deputy CEO; Telefonica - Elena Valderrabano, Chief Sustainability (ESG) Officer

Meeting US Power & Natural Gas Demand: CMS Energy - Reiji P. Hayes, EVP and Chief Financial Officer; NiSource - Shawn Anderson, EVP and Chief Financial Officer; California Resources - Clio Crespy, EVP and Chief Financial Officer

Water & Land Efficiency: Meeting Reliability, Minimizing Footprint: Jacobs Solutions - Susan Moisio, Global Water Market Director; Water Asset Management - Matthew Diserio, President; Weyerhaeuser - Ara Erickson, VP of Corporate Sustainability

Can Hard- to- Abate Sectors Decarbonize Amid Reindustrialization?: ArcelorMittal - Nicola Davidson, Vice President, Sustainable Development & Corporate Communications; Maersk - Lene Serpa, Head of Corporate Sustainability & ESG

Investing in Reliability. We believe the confluence of rising power demand, historical underinvestment in infrastructure and rising temperatures/more extreme weather events will continue to drive rising tailwinds for investments in Reliability - primarily of Power, Water and Energy. We continue to see opportunity for investment in stocks levered to the theme globally, which we believe will be a priority for both policymakers and corporate/residential consumers. Additionally, we believe the Demographic Dilemma of Aging Populations and shrinking productive labor pools in developed economies will drive significant investment opportunities and will introduce both new challenges and opportunities to solving Sustainable Development Goals.

- How much investment will go to Decarbonization vs. Adaptation, and what will be Reactive vs. Proactive? While Green Capex has been significant, impactful and resilient, we still see investment levels on track likely short of what's needed to achieve key goals around Decarbonization, Infrastructure and Clean Water. We see some areas of overlap between Decarbonization and Adaptation investment, in particular products that support Battery storage, Energy/consumption efficiency, Energy/Water infrastructure, Solar and Carbon Capture.
- What impact will changing US government incentives have on Green Capex?

The sunsetting of the Inflation Reduction Act incentives as part of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act looks to bifurcate investment resiliency among key low- carbon verticals. We continue to believe those supporting Reliability (in particular power infrastructure, utility- scale solar, onshore wind, nuclear) will be resilient, with challenges for US electric vehicles, offshore wind and green hydrogen.

Exhibit 2: We see Green Capex from public companies continuing to grow through the rest of the decade but at a slower pace vs. 2021-24; further impact possible due to US tariffs, lower economic growth Cumulative incremental Green Capex investment from public companies (2021-2031)
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 3: We believe the private sector is on track for \(\) 1.0\(tn of the incremental\) \ \(2.8\) tn Green Capex needed annually in the 2020s, though with downside risk on the back of US tariff increases and economic growth concerns; public companies have spare capacity to invest\) \ \(0.8\) tn more annually starting in 2025
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 4: Despite changes to incentives, we see robust levels of US power sector investment through 2032 driven by strong Al/data center demand and broader power infrastructure upgrades; overall investment is \(- 15\%\) vs. our estimates post- IRA, largely driven by meaningful reductions in EV- related and other low- carbon verticals
Overall 2023- 32E US investment into key low- carbon verticals, estimates post- Inflation Reduction Act vs. updates post- One Big Beautiful Bill Act
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 5: Even as we see US government outlay falling \(\) 600\(bn (50\%)\) post- OBBBA vs. the Inflation Reduction Act, we continue to expect robust US Green Capex - about\) \ \(3\) tn in 2023- 32E from key verticals - with weighting shifted to power verticals in part to meet upward revisions to both demand growth grid resiliency enhancements unrelated to incentives 2023- 32 investment in key Green Capex verticals post the 2025 One Big Beautiful Bill Act, \(\) bn
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 8: In the US, \(\sim 300K\) additional jobs, across manufacturing, construction, and operations, will be needed to meet power demand by 2030 by our estimates; we also see an additional \(\sim 207K\) jobs needed in our base case for transmission and distribution Jobs required to meet US power supply by 2030E
Source: US Department of Energy, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 9: In Europe, we estimate an additional 250K jobs will be needed by 2030 to meet new power demand growth Jobs required to meet Europe power supply 2020- 2030E

Al & Innovation Implications for Sustainability: Applied Materials - Chris Librie, Head of ESG; Morgan Stanley Investment Management - Thomas Kamei, Portfolio Manager, Tailwinds at Counterpoint Global, MSIM and Head of Sustainability
Software, Sustainability & Scale: Osapiens - Alberto Zamora, Co- Founder and Chief Executive Officer; SAP - Sophia Mendelsohn, Chief Sustainability Officer
Enabling Al/Data Centers & Grid Reliability while Minimizing Resource Footprint: Fireside chat with Prysmian: Prysmian - Massimo Battaini, Chief Executive Officer

We view power demand growth acceleration as largely unimpacted by tariff/policy/inflation uncertainty and not negatively impacted by Al efficiencies/innovation. While we do not expect Al to be the sole driver of US power demand, we still anticipate the growth of hyperscaler capex and associated power consumption will have a material influence on global power demand and market participants continue to see elevated levels of demand. Our analysis suggests a \(165\%\) increase in data center power demand by 2030 vs. 2023 levels. In the US, this implies that data centers will contribute a \(\sim 1\%\) CAGR to overall US power demand; our Utilities team expects overall US power demand CAGR of \(2.5\%\) through 2030 (after being flattish for a decade), and notes that weather normal power demand has trended strongly so far in 2025, above long- term demand CAGR of \(2.5\%\) , as per monthly EIA data. We see data centers adding a \(0.3\%\) CAGR to overall global power demand. Our base case implies data center power demand moves from \(1\% - 2\%\) of overall global power demand to \(3\% - 4\%\) by 2030. In the US, the pace of mix increase is even greater, more than doubling by 2030 from \(4\%\) in 2023.

Data center power demand, implications for renewables vs. thermal power. The need for round- the- clock power while still meeting decarbonization goals is leading to various solutions to source data center power demand directly or indirectly from low carbon sources. The percentage of data center power demand met via renewables vs. thermal (natural gas or coal) power is the subject of much investor and industry debate.

Chip efficiency gains (expanding the map of consumers of Al solutions vs. lowering overall demand for power). Power demand acceleration is expected to continue - we note that hyperscaler demand and interest levels of technology companies in signing power purchase agreements, appear inelastic to power prices/expected policy shifts. As a result, in our view, chip efficiency gains will be offset by a larger trend in the increase in customers of Al solutions.
Value of Al's potential benefits relative to potential social cost of increased

emissions. We see potential for Al benefits via speeding up drug/vaccine/therapeutic discoveries, improving crop yields, and increasing energy efficiency among other potential innovations, though with uncertainty on the magnitude and timing. The Al power surge and emissions increase is likely to prompt greater interest among Sustainable investors to quantify Al value added (similar to avoided emissions frameworks) vs. the rising emissions from Al power consumption.

Exhibit 10: After being flat over 2015- 19, we have seen data center power demand accelerate in 2021- 23 and our Utilities analysts expect a \(165\%\) increase through the rest of the decade Global data center electricity consumption, TWh; includes Al and excludes cryptocurrency
Source: Masanet et al. (2020), Cisco, IEA, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Efficiency of Buildings: Solutions Customers are Buying: Installed Building Products - Jason Niswonger, Chief Administrative and Sustainability Officer; Prologis - Suzanne Fallender, VP of Global Impact & Sustainability; Vornado - Lauren Moss, SVP & Chief Sustainability Officer

Water & Land Efficiency: Meeting Reliability, Minimizing Footprint: Jacobs Solutions - Susan Moisio, Global Water Market Director; Water Asset Management - Matthew Diserio, President; Weyerhaeuser - Ara Erickson, VP of Corporate Sustainability

Can Hard- to- Abate Sectors Decarbonize Amid Reindustrialization?: ArcelorMittal - Nicola Davidson, Vice President, Sustainable Development & Corporate Communications; Maersk - Lene Serpa, Head of Corporate Sustainability & ESG

We see tariffs, supply chain uncertainty, inflationary pressures, regulation and geologic maturity (particularly in the US and Europe) accelerating the global shift towards the Resource Efficiency Era which we believe will drive greater deployment of Circular Economy solutions to help mitigate demand growth and promote security of supply for critical materials. New tariffs and potential competition from AI power needs are also driving debates around security of US raw material supply. We expect continued investment in efficiency technologies such as recycling and circular building materials, energy emissions intensity reduction, long- term battery storage, and optimization solutions to enhance reliability/lower risk.

What will lead companies to pursue increased efficiencies through the Circular Economy? We see four key catalysts continuing to drive deployment of efficiency solutions that reduce consumption intensity or drive security of supply without impacting quality of life:

1. Rising commodity prices or input costs from supply diversification to drive an emphasis on resource efficiency amongst corporates.  
2. Rising security of supply concerns amidst geopolitical tensions and mounting export restrictions on materials critical for low carbon, automation and defense technologies.  
3. Greater recognition of circular solution contributions to low carbon and broader
sustainability goals - e.g., recycled aluminum can replace most virgin aluminum use cases and requires \(95\%\) less energy than primary aluminum.
4. Regulatory tailwinds to increase mandates and/or incentives towards recycling and circular economy solutions to help meet geopolitical and/or sustainability goals.

- Critical Raw Materials supply challenges. The geographic concentration of raw material supply chains remains a key security-of-supply concern for both the EU and the US to access the critical raw materials (CRMs) necessary for semis, defence, BEVs, and a broader renewables buildout. Latest data from the IEAs Global Critical Minerals 2025 report shows an increase in supply and refining concentrations for many critical materials including copper, lithium, cobalt, and rare earths. Mining companies will be critical enablers to a circular economy through urban mining and deployment of new technologies extracting value from existing tailings waste. Mining companies remain underweight in sustainable funds.
Exhibit 11: China maintains the largest share of refining for 19 out of the top 20 energy-related raw materials % share of top refining country for top 20 energy-related raw materials as of May 2025

Exhibit 12: Share of top 3 critical materials refining countries is not expected by the IEA to improve in the future, driven by leaders continuing to scale investment Top 3 countries % of global critical minerals refining capacity

State of Sustainable Investing: Navigating Uncertainty and Finding Opportunity: CPP Investments - Richard Manley, Chief Sustainability Officer; New York State Teachers' Retirement System - Han Yik, Senior Advisor to the ED/CIO - Stewardship; Putnam Investments - Katherine Collins, Head of Sustainable Investing

Navigating the Shifting Landscape of Regulatory, Asset Owner and Corporate Expectations: Goldman Sachs - James Norman, Global Head of Sustainable Investing Client Strategy, GSAM; LRQA - Kevin Franklin, Chief Product Officer, LRQA and Chief Executive Officer, EiQ
Evolution of Sustainability Leadership: Adapting to Today's Challenges & Opportunities: Amcor - David Clark, Chief Sustainability Officer; IBM - Christina Shim, Chief Sustainability Officer

The Sustainable Investing debate continues amid a tougher period of fund performance. Among Sustainable investors, we are currently seeing a re- emphasis on materiality, portfolio diversification, and the business case for Sustainable impact. We continue to see movement towards greater engagement and expanding investable universes, while further opportunity remains, in our view. We also note shifting regulations and investor trends as potentially indicative of further maturation of Sustainable Investing from the initial Socially Responsible Investment Phase to the more recent ESG Phase to now the Sustainable Investment Phase, which we believe will be characterized by: (a) a shift in focus from process to outcomes; (b) greater emphasis on Sustainable metrics linkages to stock performance; and (c) an expansion of the investable universe across the supply chain.

Expanding the investable universe. We have seen some continued movement towards expanding investable universes, while further opportunity remains, in our view. For example, our latest analysis of Sustainable Investment fund holdings continues to point to an ongoing softening of industry- level over- and- underweights. We observe a sustained trend of lower levels of deviation across SI Industry over- and- underweights since 2021, indicative of an overall broadening of SI strategies. One notable exception to this trend are often- excluded Industries by SI funds (Tobacco, Aerospace & Defense and Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels), which not have seen material net decreases in their SI underweights over this period.

Measuring Sustainable Quality. GS SUSTAIN has long defined the hallmark of quality as those businesses able to generate consistently superior returns on capital. We view a company's resource utilization, management of human capital, corporate

reputation, regulatory compliance, etc. (elements encompassed within 'Operational' Sustainability analysis) as complementary to the Quality mosaic, helping investors better know what they own and offering measurable insights into how a company is managed. We aim to focus on the material E, S & G measures that are most likely to have an influence on company fundamentals.

Evolving investor trends. Sustainability- related regulations and investor trends have evolved amid Sustainable fund underperformance, continuing inflation concerns, and shifting political landscapes in 2025. From client conversations across the US, Europe, and APAC, we note continued interest from investors in investment in power sourcing and infrastructure reliability, heavier focus on material, higher quality quantitative metrics, and the broadening of the Sustainable Investment opportunity set.

Sustainable Finance: Liquidity, Returns, Uncertainty, Opportunity: BNP Paribas - Ravina Advani, Head of Low- Carbon Transition & Infrastructure Group; Goldman Sachs - Eduardo Manzur, Sector Captain for Energy Technology, Investment Banking Division; J.P. Morgan - Michael Johnson, Vice Chairman of Natural Resources Investment Banking

A tougher period of performance for Sustainable funds as well as broader maturation of data availability and investor focus are driving increased investor attention on linkages between Sustainable fund strategies and share price performance. As mentioned above, GS SUSTAIN defines Quality businesses as those able to generate consistently superior returns on capital. We believe Sustainable Investors can further prioritize sustainable metrics based on relevancy, what's quantifiable, and application across sectors. We continue to recommend a concentric circles approach fusing relevant Sustainability metrics with financial fundamentals. Increasingly, we believe companies that can demonstrate they are low- cost, low environmental footprint and safe suppliers can receive greater Sustainable investor support.

Sustainable "Metrics that Matter" (i.e., link to equity performance) vs. those that are less relevant. We are seeing a re- emphasis on materiality and the business case for sustainability initiatives from asset owners and asset managers. While not everything will necessarily be a win/win (i.e., positive for both sustainability and financial objectives), we continue to believe that material sustainability considerations can support key generalist objectives such as efficiency, resilience, innovation and risk mitigation. We continue to advocate for a "concentric circles" approach of prioritizing areas of overlap between sustainability and more traditional financial characteristics.
Themes/sectors that may be elevated above uncertainty (policy, rates, inflation, etc). We observe a sustained trend of lower levels of deviation across SI

Industry over- and- underweights since 2021, indicative of an overall broadening of SI strategies. Utilities, while overweighted by SI funds, have seen a 38 pp drop in their ownership since 3Q21, driven by decreasing exposure to Renewable Energy, a category that has hampered SI fund performance over this period. Notably, we still see opportunity for broader sponsorship of Utilities deploying Green Capex as investment is prioritized to maintain reliability of power/water to meet rising power demand and mitigate impact of aging infrastructure and more extreme temperatures/weather events. Overall, we continue to highlight confluence across several of our Sustainability themes this year, including Future of Work, Efficiency of Energy, Resources & Land, Reliability, and Resilient Green Capex.

Our offering of SUSTAIN tools can help investors to answer Sustainability questions at the portfolio and security levels, enabling more systematized and quantitative reporting while providing detailed and transparent data sets for idea generation, security selection and corporate engagement.

Our multi- pronged SUSTAIN performance framework can help provide greater granularity and objectivity for asset managers in both security selection and reporting. The framework across \(>7000\) companies includes our recently introduced Product Alignment framework, based on the SDGs, EU Taxonomy and GS analyst views, and can help investors cast a wider net in the search for impact ideas aligned to less obvious sustainability themes. Existing pillars detail performance around sector- specific environmental and social operational metrics, governance, and controversies.

Forward- looking estimates. Looking ahead, we believe investment performance will be more driven by future change and have taken our steps toward incorporating forward- looking estimates in our proprietary industry analyst inputs, which now include sustainable product revenue and capex in select industries. We also have analyst estimates for Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions for a smaller segment of companies in 10 sectors.

EU Taxonomy revenue alignment. We see the EU Taxonomy as one of the most seminal regulatory developments driving standardization in reporting for corporates/asset managers. Our EU Taxonomy alignment tool maps company revenues to Taxonomy- defined activities to estimate potential Taxonomy- eligible and aligned revenue based on technical screening checks where data exist, and "Do No Significant Harm" and "Minimum Social Safeguards" criteria.

SDG revenue alignment. The UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) have emerged as one of the most commonly used frameworks for taxonomizing impact across a broad set of sustainability challenges. Our SDG alignment tool employs granular revenue data, GS analyst inputs and other company metadata to map alignment, exposure and misalignment to ten of the SDGs we deem to be most investable.

Sustainable fund ownership. Aggregating fund holdings across a universe of \(\sim 4,000\) Sustainable funds, we analyze this pool of Sustainable investing assets to better understand trends in Sustainable fund ownership at both the sector and company level. The full dataset provides absolute and momentum Sustainable fund ownership detail for well over 10,000 securities.

Sustainable fund flows, valuations and performance. Our SUSTAIN Tracker series analyzes the aforementioned Sustainable fund universe to gauge Sustainable fund flow momentum and sizing relative to the broader market, breaking out differences by strategy, fund type and fund style. The tracker also examines valuation and performance across categories.
Climate Transition Tool, Circular Economy and Nature Ecosystems. These tools

help investors to answer more targeted questions about the transparency and performance of a company's climate transition plans, how well a company is adapting its business or enabling customers to be more circular or a company's exposure, transparency, strategy and performance on four key drivers influencing nature outcomes.
Exhibit 22: How GS SUSTAIN can help: Data tools, themes, trends and ideas
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We, Brian Singer, CFA, Evan Tylenda, CFA, Brendan Corbett, Grace Chen, Varsha Venugopal, Xavier Zhang and Shubham Jain, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when

Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.

labels: Spare capacity from public companies starting in 2025

figures.title: Total US investment in key Green Capex verticals, 2023-2032

y.unit: Total jobs per MW installed capacity

series.name: Mean
series.unit: Total jobs per MW installed capacity

series.name: Error Bar Min
series.unit: Total jobs per MW installed capacity

series.name: Error Bar Max
series.unit: Total jobs per MW installed capacity

figures.title: Circular Economy vs. Linear Economy: Increasing Circularity

values.description: Make product redundant by abandoning its function or by offering the same function with a radically different product
Make product use more intensive (e.g. by sharing product)
Increase efficiency in product manufacture or use by consuming fewer natural resources and materials
Reuse by another consumer of discarded product which is still in good condition and fulfills its original function
Repair and maintenance of defective product so it can be used with its original function
Restore an old product and bring it up to date
Use parts of discarded product in a new product with the same function
Use discarded product or its parts in a new product with a different function
Process materials to obtain the same or lower quality
Incineration of material with energy recovery

figures.title: Phases of ESG Investing / Evolution of Market Demands

values.description: Phase focused on values alignment and emergence of other ESG-linked strategies
market_demands: Box ticking (e.g., Is ESG considered, incorporated? Y/N)

values.description: Phase defined by resource building and policy & process development
market_demands: Hiring & installing ESG leadership and support, including stewardship and engagement resourcing
implications_for_stock_selection: Emphasis on disclosure leads to large-cap bias

values.description: Phase defined by rapid asset gathering and increasing emphasis on thematic alignment
market_demands: Demand for commitments to long-range initiatives
Demands for more granular reporting (e.g., carbon footprint, product alignment, voting & engagement)
implications_for_stock_selection: Rapid asset gathering, 'TOME' further spurring exclusions

values.description: Broadening of applications and shift in focus from process to outcomes
market_demands: Increasing focus on links to fundamentals & performance
implications_for_stock_selection: Mitigation of historic industry overweights and underweights
Refinement of product offerings to meet diverse requirements (e.g., integration, thematic, transition, etc.)

values.description: Holistic incorporation: ESG analysis subsumed into investment analysis
market_demands: More accepted, well demonstrated links to fundamentals & performance
implications_for_stock_selection: Relevant for all styles, all asset classes (e.g., value, alternatives)

values.name: Green Capex
values.description: Impact across supply chain from $6.0 trillion/yr capex needed this decade to support Net Zero, Infrastructure, Clean Water goals; US Policy impact; Climate Transition transparency & performance

values.name: AI Impact
values.description: AI/Data center power demand/emissions outlook and Green Reliability Premiums; potential AI sustainability benefits/risks

values.name: Adaptation
values.description: Implications of rising temperatures on physical risk, financial risk, needed investment and investment beneficiaries; framework for assessing physical risk to nine hazards

values.name: Circular Economy
values.description: Beneficiaries from rising deployment of resource efficiency solutions to reduce resource consumption; framework for measuring adopters and enablers

values.name: Biodiversity
values.description: Solutions providers for and revenue beneficiaries of biodiversity conservation and risk management leaders and improvers

values.name: Aging Populations & Affordability
values.description: Impact from Aging Populations/related labor challenges and solutions corporates/governments may deploy, contributors to expansion of access/affordability in SDG-aligned Social categories

values.name: ESG Integration
values.description: The PM's Guide to the ESG Revolution helps investors navigate the current ESG landscape, fusing data tools and scoring metrics with the ESG investing life cycle

values.name: Regulation
values.description: Implications for investors from the EU Green Taxonomy, SFDR, CSRD and ESG regulatory efforts in the US and Asia Pacific

values.name: Improvers & Greenablers
values.description: Identifying transformations via forward-looking estimates on Green Revenue, Green Capex and Greenhouse Gas Emissions by company by year; Avoided Emissions framework at sector level

values.name: Capital Flows & Trends
values.description: ESG fund flows, top ESG fund holdings and where we see crowding of over/underweight positions, Exclusion vs. Engagement, ESG shift From Aspiration to Action
